verses.text: So these three men stopped answering Job, because he was righteous in his own eyes.
verses.comment: Job’s friends have reached the end of their arguments, convinced of Job’s self-righteousness. This sets up the introduction of a new voice, hinting at the need for a mediator to bridge gaps in understanding, foreshadowing the importance of intercession (cf. 1 Tim. 2:5).

verses.text: Then the anger of Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite, of the family of Ram, burned against Job. His anger burned because Job justified himself rather than God.
verses.comment: Elihu introduces a youthful perspective, angered not by malice but by zeal for truth. The theme of justification before God is crucial: true righteousness must come from God, not from self-justification—foreshadowing the doctrine of righteousness imparted by divine grace (Rom. 3:21–26).

verses.text: He was also angry at his three friends because they had found no answer, yet condemned Job.
verses.comment: Elihu’s indignation exposes the failure of mere human wisdom. The need for an authoritative tradition and rightly-ordered judgment is highlighted here, anticipating the value of a divinely guided community’s teaching authority.

verses.text: Now Elihu had waited to speak to Job because they were older than he.
verses.comment: Respect for elders is here shown, consistent with biblical virtue (Lev. 19:32). Yet, Elihu’s arrival shows that authentic wisdom may break into tradition even from unexpected places, as seen throughout salvation history.

verses.text: When Elihu saw that there was no answer in the mouths of these three men, his anger burned.
verses.comment: Elihu’s zeal represents righteous indignation, pointing to the prophets and the saints’ boldness in defense of truth (Jer. 20:9). Sometimes, reform and admonition come from those who seem least likely.

verses.text: Elihu the son of Barachel the Buzite spoke out and said: “I am young in years, and you are old; therefore I was timid and afraid to declare my opinion to you.
verses.comment: Elihu’s humility, and awareness of his own youth, recalls the humble yet bold witness required of God’s servants (1 Tim. 4:12).

verses.text: I said, ‘Days should speak, and many years should teach wisdom.’
verses.comment: Traditionally, age is linked with wisdom, indicating the importance of tradition and the value of passed-down teaching (Deut. 32:7). But God’s Spirit may raise up the humble, emphasizing the virtue of humility in hearing God’s voice.

verses.text: But it is the spirit in a man, the breath of the Almighty, that gives them understanding.
verses.comment: True understanding is ultimately a gift from God’s Spirit (Isa. 11:2). This points beyond mere human effort and anticipates the gifting of the Holy Spirit to all believers (John 16:13).

verses.text: It is not the great who are wise, nor do the aged understand justice.
verses.comment: Here, Elihu highlights human limitations. Divine wisdom sometimes upends human expectations, as when God chooses the lowly (Luke 1:52).

verses.text: Therefore I say, ‘Listen to me; I will also declare my opinion.’
verses.comment: Inspired by the Spirit, even the young may speak truth with authority—a reminder that God often works through those open to His promptings.

verses.text: Look, I waited for your words; I listened to your reasonings, while you searched out what to say.
verses.comment: Elihu respectfully listened first, suggesting that genuine dialogue and patience are necessary for discernment.

verses.text: I gave you my attention, but there was not one of you who convinced Job or answered his words.
verses.comment: Their inability to answer Job completely points to the limitations of unaided reason in deep questions of suffering, reinforcing the need for revealed wisdom.

verses.text: Beware lest you say, ‘We have found wisdom; God may vanquish him, not a man.’
verses.comment: Elihu warns against pride in self-sufficiency, pointing to the need for humility before God’s revelations and judgments. Only God is ultimately wise.

verses.text: He has not directed his words against me, and I will not answer him with your arguments.
verses.comment: Elihu indicates he will approach Job differently—open to God’s Spirit, not bound by previous human arguments. There is a model here of ecclesial renewal that is neither innovation nor mere repetition.

verses.text: They are dismayed; they answer no more; words have deserted them.
verses.comment: The end of human ability to answer reveals the need for God’s intervention—God’s grace perfects and completes what nature cannot.

verses.text: Should I wait, because they do not speak, because they stand there and answer no more?
verses.comment: Elihu sees a purpose in this silence—a readiness to hear a fresh word, echoing moments throughout Scripture where new revelation follows stillness (1 Kings 19:12).

verses.text: I also will answer my part; I too will declare my opinion.
verses.comment: Elihu’s willingness to speak up shows spiritual courage. The body of Christ is built as each member fulfills their calling.

verses.text: For I am full of words; the spirit within me compels me.
verses.comment: Elihu claims divine inspiration, paralleling prophetic calls like Jeremiah’s (Jer. 20:9). God’s Spirit moves individuals to speak for the good of the community.

verses.text: Look, my heart is like wine that has no vent; like new wineskins, it is about to burst.
verses.comment: The image of wine parallels the inner compulsion of God’s message. Echoes of this appear in Jesus’ teaching on wineskins (Matt. 9:17), revealing God’s truth often requires new forms for new times.

verses.text: I must speak and find relief; I must open my lips and answer.
verses.comment: Authentic words inspired by God bring relief and truth, not only for the speaker but for listeners (cf. Acts 2:4).

verses.text: I will not show partiality to anyone, nor will I flatter any man.
verses.comment: True judgment requires impartiality. This consistent scriptural theme points to God’s justice rightly applied through His chosen instruments.

verses.text: For I do not know how to flatter, or my Maker would soon take me away.
verses.comment: Faithfulness to God’s word is key; Elihu would rather risk human disapproval than divine judgment—anticipating the call to authentic, spirit-led ministry (Gal. 1:10).
